item.title: CVE-2023-51364, CVE-2023-51365 in QNAP QTS — Remote Code Execution
item.description: A chain of vulnerabilities in QNAP NAS devices allowed a local or remote attacker to reliably gain code execution with root privilege.

item.title: CVE-2021-38666 in Windows — Remote Code Execution in the RDP client
item.description: In Microsoft Remote Desktop, a malicious RDP server could remotely execute code in a client through the RDPDR extension (enabled by default).

item.title: CVE-2021-38665 in Windows — Remote Heap Leak in the RDP client
item.description: In Microsoft Remote Desktop, a malicious RDP server could remotely leak heap memory from a client through the RDPDR extension (enabled by default).

item.title: CVE-2021-37595 in FreeRDP — Remote Arbitrary File Read
item.description: In FreeRDP < 2.4.0 (Windows), a malicious RDP server can remotely read arbitrary files from a client's system through the clipboard extension (enabled by default).

item.title: CVE-2021-37594 in FreeRDP — Remote Memory Leak
item.description: In FreeRDP < 2.4.0 (Windows), a malicious RDP server can remotely leak memory from a client's system through the clipboard extension (enabled by default).

item.title: SSTIC Challenge 2025: Writeup
item.description: A detailed walkthrough of the renowned SSTIC challenge's 2025 edition, featuring reverse engineering, deobfuscation, browser exploit, cryptography and steganography.

item.title: Patching Steam binaries
item.description: Patching Steam executable files can prove useful for diverse purposes, one of those being vulnerability research in the Steam client. This short post will explain how you can circumvent a few obstacles to achieve that, before presenting an applied example.

item.title: ECW CTF 2021: Pipe Dream (Writeup)
item.description: From October 8th to October 24th took place the online qualification round for the European Cyber Week CTF Finals, that are held every year in Rennes, France. I had the opportunity to create a reverse engineering challenge for this event as part of an internship at Thalium.

item.title: About me
item.description:
I am a security researcher at Thalium.

I specialize in reverse engineering and vulnerability research. I am interested in low level security, fuzzing, binary exploitation techniques and mitigations. I also enjoy cryptography.

Previously, I have played CTFs with SHRECS, a team that I created with fellow students of my university. During that time, we helped promoting the CTF culture in CentraleSupélec, and won multiple competitions such as Imperial CTF, HackDay, THCon CTF and Orange CTF.

item.title: Challenges
item.description:
As much as I love solving CTF challenges, I also greatly enjoy designing my own puzzles. This page indexes some challenges I have created in the past for various occasions (not an exhaustive list).

SSTIC 2024: The Green Shard Brawl

#pwn #linux #heap

A binary exploitation problem created for the renowned, annual SSTIC challenge. It consists of a Linux client for a multi-player SDL game written in C, and a Python server that implements a custom protocol. The goal is to spawn a reverse shell on another player’s machine solely by interacting with the server.
